thread.title_full: This new social media game is terrifying parents | New York Post

author: Hayley Richardson, The Sun
title: This new social media game is terrifying parents | New York Post
text:
A disturbing trend which encourages school children to scrub at the skin on their arms with a rubber while reciting the alphabet is gathering steam on social media.
The Eraser Challenge – known by some parents as The ABC Game – is won by the person who ends up with the biggest wound.
The foolish stunt first came to peoples’ attention in February last year, with children sharing snaps of their bloodied arms on social media sites like Instagram.
It later evolved, with kids reciting a variety of different things as they gouged, and was even combined with other trends such as the salt and ice challenge .
This involved school-age children putting salt and ice on their skin which causes a chemical reaction, lowering the temperature of the ice to the extreme of 1.4 degrees Fahrenheit.
The challenge was how long the person could put up with the pain of the freezing process, which leaves a burn similar to frostbite on the skin.
Kids then posted snaps of their war wounds online.
Some children were admitted to hospital as their burns were so extreme, reported Kidspot .
Now the Eraser Challenge is sparking fresh concern among worried parents as the number of images shared on social media is on the climb.
#eraserchallenge its stupid 
A post shared by Jackattack (@j4ck4tt4ck44) on Jan 19, 2016 at 9:35pm PST 
Reassuringly, many of the comments on the gruesome pictures render the game “stupid” and “idiotic”, and several kids have expressed regret for taking part.
One mom shared a picture of a healing eraser burn , writing: “In this edition of stupid things 6th graders talk each other into: The Eraser Challenge.
“The result: permanent scars. This made me very sad, but satisfied as the boy told me how badly his arm hurt many days later and how he would never try anything like that again.”
The dangers of social media trends among young people were laid bare recently, when we reported how a mom issued a warning to other parents about a disturbing Snapchat bullying game.
This involved teens competing to see who could say the cruelest thing about a chosen victim.
In January, we told how there were fears bored teens were dislocating their thumbs ‘for fun’ as people shared revolting photos of their mangled digits alongside bizarre how-to posts.
And last year we told how teens viciously insulted each other online as part of a social media trend called the Huh Challenge.
